Note.Content: In contexts where an accompanying expression designates movement into an area, ἐν[a] and εἰς[d] may be rendered as ‘into.’

There are no doubt certain subtle distinctions in the meanings of the terms in {D:83.9}. For example, πρός[d] may suggest some kind of interaction or response and παρά[b] may focus upon association, but it is difficult, if not impossible, on the basis of existing contexts to define precisely the differences in meaning.
Attendant circumstances are often expressed in English by participial or gerund phrases.

Manner is expressed in a number of different ways in diverse languages. In English it is often expressed by means of a phrase introduced by with, but the appropriate equivalent in some contexts is simply an adverb. Often, however, an entire clause or additional complete sentence is required.
As will be noted in a number of instances of markers of experiencer relations, there may be no lexical item in a translation which specifically corresponds to such a marker.
There are probably certain subtle distinctions between the use of διά[c] in contrast with εἰς[h] or ἐν[p] as markers of means, but this cannot be clearly determined from existing contexts.

The difference in meaning between the set κατά[g], ἐπί[s], ἐν[s], ἐκ[k], and καθώς[d] and the set πότε, ποτέ[b], ὁπότε, ὅτε[a], and ὅταν[b] ({D:67.30}) is largely a matter of class meanings, but there may be certain subtle rhetorical differences as well.
It would seem that the meanings of items {D:70.1}-{D:70.4} do reflect certain subtle differences, but it is not at all easy to determine precisely how they differ.

The series of expressions indicating relative shortness of time may very well differ slightly, at least in connotative meaning, but on the basis of existing NT contexts it is not possible to determine significant denotative differences. The phrases in this series may be technically regarded as idioms, but functionally they are better classed as frozen phrases, which act essentially like morphological units.
It is very possible that the two idioms in {D:28.64} differ somewhat in meaning, or at least in connotation, but it is difficult, if not impossible, to show this from existing contexts.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a position defined as being within certain limits{N:001}
LEXSense.Comments: Some translations render {S:04100500300010} as ‘he lived among the graves,’ but it is likely that the Greek expression refers to living within relatively elaborate tombs.|In {S:04100200800038} it is also possible to understand the phrase ἐν ἑαυτοῖς as meaning ‘among themselves’ (see ἐν[b], {D:83.9}).|It may not be possible in some languages to speak of a part of a document as being ‘in’ something. It may, therefore, be necessary to render this expression in {S:04600500900006} as ‘part of what I wrote to you about was …’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a position within an area determined by other objects and distributed among such objects{N:002}

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: On, Upon, On the Surface Of

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a position on the surface of an area
LEXSense.Comments: In a number of languages it may be quite impossible to speak of ‘tablets of the human heart’ ({S:04700300300042}). An equivalent may be ‘in the human heart’ or ‘in people’s hearts.’ In some languages, however, it may be necessary to substitute ‘mind,’ for example, ‘in people’s minds.’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a position in proximity to or in the immediate vicinity of an object or other position
a marker of a state or condition
extension toward a goal which is inside an area
LEXSense.Comments: This meaning is also found as a variant reading: ἄγγελος γὰρ κυρίου κατὰ καιρὸν κατέβαινεν ἐν τῇ κολυμβήθρᾳ ‘an angel of the Lord from time to time went down into the pool’ {S:04300500300018} (apparatus).

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of close personal association
a marker of attendant circumstances, often with the implication of means{N:003}
(with the dative) a marker of an immediate instrument
a marker of the manner in which an event occurs{N:004}
LEXSense.Comments: In some languages it may be better to restructure this statement in {S:04501200800034} and translate ‘one should be generous in sharing with others.’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of an area of activity which bears some relation to something else
a marker of that of which something consists
a marker of an experiencer of an event{N:005}
LEXSense.Comments: It is also possible to interpret the relation expressed by ἐν in {S:04800101600010} as indicating agent or instrument, for example, ‘to reveal his Son by me’ or ‘… through my life’ (compare ἐν as an expression of agent in {D:90.6} and instrument in {D:90.10}), or even means (ἐν ἐμοί referring to his behavior) as in {D:89.76}.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Agent, Personal or Nonpersonal, Causative or Immediate, Direct or Indirect

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (with the dative) a marker of agent, often with the implication of an agent being used as an instrument, and in some instances relating to general behavior rather than to some specific event
a marker of objects which serve as symbolic substitutes for supernatural persons or powers presumed to act as guarantors of compliance with oaths
(with the dative) a marker of the means by which one event makes another event possible{N:006}
a marker of cause or reason, with focus upon instrumentality, either of objects or events
a marker of result, with the probable implication of a preceding process
LEXSense.Comments: In some languages this expression in {S:04200101700036} may be rendered as ‘to cause the disobedient people to think like the righteous.’

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: A Point of Time with Reference to Other Points of Time: Before, Long Ago, Now, At the Same Time, When, About, After

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of a point of time which is simultaneous to or overlaps with another point of time{N:007}

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time with Reference to Some Unit of Time: During, In, While, Throughout

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of the extent of time within a unit
(with the dative) a marker of content as a means of specifying a particular referent
(an idiom: in truth) pertaining to being a real or actual event or state{N:008}
(an idiom, literally: to be in weight, see {D:86.1}) to insist on one’s importance or worth
LEXSense.Comments: It is possible to interpret ἐν βάρει εἰμί as denoting a person’s status, and accordingly, one could classify this idiom in Domain 87 Status, but it is also possible to interpret this expression in {S:05200200700006} as the demands which could be placed upon persons, and therefore one could translate as ‘we could have made demands on you.’ Such a translation would imply the relationship of authority, and the meaning could be classified in Domain 37 Control, Rule.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to have in the womb) to be in a state of pregnancy.
LEXSense.Comments: This expression contrasts with the meaning of {L:συλλαμβάνω<SDBG:συλλαμβάνω:000001>}[b], {D:23.49}, in that it seems to focus more upon the state of pregnancy rather than the event of conception.|It is impossible to determine whether in {S:04000102300008} (ἐν γαστρὶ ἕξει καὶ τέξεται υἱόν ‘she will be pregnant and bear a son’) the focus is upon the state of pregnancy or the fact of conception (see {D:23.49}).

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time without Reference to Points or Units of Time: Time, Spend Time, Always, Eternal, Old, Immediately, Young

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in great) pertaining to a relatively long duration of time

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time without Reference to Points or Units of Time: Time, Spend Time, Always, Eternal, Old, Immediately, Young

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: ἐν ὀλίγῳ - pertaining to a relatively brief extent of time{N:009}
LEXSense.Comments: It is also possible to interpret ἐν ὀλίγῳ in {S:04402602800014} as meaning ‘easily’ or ‘without difficulty’ (see {D:22.41}).

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: pertaining to that which is accomplished easily or without difficulty
LEXSense.Comments: For another, more probable, interpretation of ἐν ὀλίγῳ in {S:04402602800014}, see {D:67.106}.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: pertaining to expressions which are not to be understood literally, but symbolically or figuratively
LEXSense.Comments: In a number of languages it may be more satisfactory to translate ἐν παραβολῇ and πνευματικῶς[c] by a negative expression, for example, ‘not literally’ or ‘not really.’ The expression in {S:06601100800028} might be translated as ‘that city might be called Sodom, but it isn’t really Sodom.’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in boldness) in an evident or publicly known manner

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time without Reference to Points or Units of Time: Time, Spend Time, Always, Eternal, Old, Immediately, Young

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in the blinking of an eye) an extremely short duration of time
LEXSense.Comments: For another interpretation of the phrase ἐν ῥιπῇ ὀφθαλμοῦ, see {D:16.5}.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time without Reference to Points or Units of Time: Time, Spend Time, Always, Eternal, Old, Immediately, Young

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a very brief period of time

Glosses.Gloss: quickly (in combination with the preposition ἐν)

LEXSense.Comments: In {S:04402201800018} τάχος evidently refers to a brief period of time before fulfilling the admonition to leave Jerusalem.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Not Able To Be Known, Secret

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in the darkness) pertaining to not being able to be known by the public but known by some in-group or by those immediately involved

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: A Point of Time with Reference to Other Points of Time: Before, Long Ago, Now, At the Same Time, When, About, After

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in the next) a point of time subsequent to another point of time, but with the implication of an ordered sequence

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Not Able To Be Known, Secret

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in the hidden) pertaining to not being able to be known by the public but known by some in-group or by those immediately involved

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time with Reference to Some Unit of Time: During, In, While, Throughout

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: in the between) an extent of time within another unit or extension of time
(an idiom, literally: in the light) pertaining to being widely known in view of the events in question having taken place in public{N:010}

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time with Reference to Some Unit of Time: During, In, While, Throughout

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: an extent of time of the same length as another extent or unit of time
